comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toru%C5%84 "Toruń [ˈtɔruɲ] ( listen) (German: Thorn (Ltspkr.png listen), Kashubian: Torń, Latin: Thorunium, see also: other names) is an ancient city in northern Poland, on the Vistula River." Bridge appears to still be there. See www.panoramio.com/photo/65793134

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=b965bc969be46... is a diagram/model of the bridge

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See NYT of April 4, 1915 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10E12FA395B1773... for an essay on the possible "reconstruction" of Poland. It begins, "In spite of its vagueness, the Grand Duke Nicholas's proclamation justifies the most sanguine hopes. This has been recognized not only by all the Poles whom it has reached, those of Russian Poland, and the three million Polish refugees who live in America, but moreover, all the Allies have interpreted it as a genuine promise that Poland would be territorially and politically re-constructed." I think the "proclamation" mentioned is probably one from the previous year in which Nicholas asked for support from Poles in return for autonomy. See NYT of August 16, 1914 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C15F938591673...
